title: 105_hr3568
content: The Act titled "Mental Health and Substance Abuse Parity Amendments of 1998" revises limits on mental health benefits. The Mental Health and Substance Abuse Parity Amendments of 1998 expand coverage under ERISA for group health plans and insurance to include mental health benefits without imposing treatment limitations or financial requirements if not imposed on medical and surgical benefits. The Mental Health and Substance Abuse Parity Amendments of 1998 require group health plans to provide mental health benefits without treatment limitations or financial requirements, such as negotiating separate reimbursement rates and managing benefit provision through mechanisms like pre-admission screening. The Mental Health and Substance Abuse Parity Amendments of 1998 mandate group health plans to offer mental health benefits without treatment limitations or financial requirements like copayments, deductibles, and annual limits. Amendments include eliminating cost exemptions and sunset provisions in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendments mandate group health plans to provide mental health benefits without treatment limitations or financial requirements if similar restrictions are not imposed on medical and surgical benefits in comparable settings. The plans are not prohibited from negotiating separate reimbursement rates or managing benefits through pre-admission screening and prior authorization. The amendments require group health plans to provide mental health benefits without treatment or financial limits. This includes limits on frequency of treatment, copayments, deductibles, and other financial requirements. Additionally, cost exemptions and sunset provisions are eliminated from the section. The item relating to section 9812 in the table of sections of subchapter B of chapter 100 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by striking "certain". Part B of title XXVII of the Public Health Service Act is amended to include new section after section 2751. "SEC. 2752. PARITY IN THE APPLICATION OF LIMITS TO MENTAL HEALTH BENEFITS." The provisions of section 2705 apply to health insurance coverage in the individual market as they do in connection with a group health plan. Effective dates for group health plans begin on or after July 1, 1999, with exceptions for plans under collective bargaining agreements ratified before the enactment of this Act. The amendment made by subsection (d) applies to individual health insurance coverage in the market starting July 1, 1999. Coordination in implementation is effective upon the enactment of the Act. The HIPAA of 1996 is amended to include provisions from other acts related to health insurance. The HIPAA of 1996 is amended to include provisions related to parity in the application of limits to substance abuse and chemical dependency benefits for group health plans under ERISA and the Public Health Service Act. The HIPAA of 1996 is amended to include provisions for parity in applying limits to substance abuse and chemical dependency benefits in group health plans under ERISA and the Public Health Service Act. This ensures that benefits for treatment of substance abuse or chemical dependency are treated the same as mental health benefits. The HIPAA of 1996 is amended to include parity in applying limits to substance abuse and chemical dependency benefits in group health plans under ERISA and the Public Health Service Act. This ensures that benefits for treatment of substance abuse or chemical dependency are treated the same as mental health benefits. Additionally, a new section is added to ensure parity in the application of limits to mental health benefits. The provisions of section 2752 apply to substance abuse or chemical dependency treatment benefits in group health plans, effective for plan years starting on or after July 1, 1999. For plans under collective bargaining agreements, the amendments do not apply before the termination of the agreements. The amendment made by subsection (d) applies to individual health insurance coverage in the market on or after July 1, 1999. Any plan amendment made to conform to new requirements shall not terminate collective bargaining agreements.
